G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject-matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because Plaintiff seeks damages in an amount greater than $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7\u00a7 3(a)\u2013(d).proposition: This Court has personal jurisdiction over Defendant pursuant to G.L. c. 223A, §§ 3(a)–(d), because Defendant transacts business in Massachusetts, contracts to supply services or things in Massachusetts, and committed a tortious act within Massachusetts causing injury to Plaintiff in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and G.L. c. 223, § 8 because the cause of action arose in Middlesex County, specifically at Defendant’s store located at 123 Market Street, Lowell, MA 01852.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 8.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and G.L. c. 223, § 8 because the cause of action arose in Middlesex County, specifically at Defendant’s store located at 123 Market Street, Lowell, MA 01852.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a business invitee, a duty of reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition, to protect Plaintiff against unreasonable risks of harm of which Defendant knew or should have known, and to warn Plaintiff of any such dangers that were not open and obvious.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a business invitee, a duty of reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition, to protect Plaintiff against unreasonable risks of harm of which Defendant knew or should have known, and to warn Plaintiff of any such dangers that were not open and obvious.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolishes the traditional common‑law distinction between licensees and invitees in Massachusetts and replaces it with a general duty of reasonable care owed to all lawful visitors. The quoted concurring passage criticizes retaining categorical distinctions, and the majority opinion does not frame the duty specifically in terms of ‘business invitees’ or the invitee‑style formulation of duty used in the proposition. Thus, the case does not support the proposition that a distinct business‑invitee duty, as described, governs; instead it supports a unified reasonable‑care standard to all lawful entrants.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.

Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206 (1978.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a business invitee, a duty of reasonable care to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition, to protect Plaintiff against unreasonable risks of harm of which Defendant knew or should have known, and to warn Plaintiff of any such dangers that were not open and obvious.
Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206 (1978.support_reasoning: The excerpted text only discusses that the case was tried and argued under a ‘hidden defect’ theory and that the evidence was sufficient to support a plaintiff’s verdict on that theory. It does not set out, adopt, or clearly describe the general duty rule toward a business invitee, nor does it address the ‘open and obvious’ limitation articulated in the proposition. Without more of the opinion, this citation does not clearly establish the specific duty language claimed.
Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206 (1978.relevant_excerpt: “This action was tried by the parties and submitted to the jury on the plaintiff’s claim that he was injured by reason of a hidden or concealed defect on the defendant’s premises, of which defect the defendant was aware or should have been aware through the exercise of reasonable care. The jury returned a substantial verdict for the plaintiff. … [T]his court is ordering that the verdict and judgment for the plaintiff be reinstated, holding that the evidence was sufficient to support the verdict.”

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Defendant either created this dangerous condition by stacking and displaying the heavy boxes in this manner, or allowed this condition to exist for a sufficient time that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable inspection and maintenance procedures, should have discovered and remedied it.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The proposition describes the traditional premises liability rule that a defendant is liable if it created the dangerous condition or allowed it to exist long enough that reasonable inspection should have discovered and remedied it. Sheehan, however, expressly moves away from that traditional notice framework in self‑service store cases and adopts the mode‑of‑operation approach, under which proof of the store’s self‑service mode substitutes for proof that defendant created the condition or had time‑based notice of it. Thus, the case does not support the quoted traditional notice proposition; it refines and partially replaces it in this context.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “Under the traditional approach to premises liability, the plaintiff is required to prove a grocery store caused a substance, matter, or item to be on the floor; the store operator had actual knowledge of its presence; or the substance, matter, or item had been on the floor so long that the store operator should have been aware of the condition… Of the two modern approaches… the mode of operation approach is in our view the more preferable, and we now adopt it.”

Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.proposition: Defendant’s failure to take reasonable steps to prevent such an occurrence was a breach of the standard of care owed to customers like Plaintiff.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.support_reasoning: The proposition assumes that the defendant owed a standard of care to the plaintiff and breached it by failing to take reasonable preventive steps. Ulwick holds the opposite: that, on these facts, a social host who did not serve or provide the alcohol owes no common-law duty to third parties injured by an intoxicated guest, and that violation of certain alcohol-related statutes does not itself create a civil duty. Thus, the case rejects, rather than supports, the asserted duty/breach formulation.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.relevant_excerpt: "We think the factor of control should continue to be the dominant consideration in a case of this type... In the absence of such control in this case, we are not prepared to say that the common law should provide a remedy on the negligent encouragement theory advanced by the plaintiff.... Since no common law duty exists here, it follows that the statutes relied on by the plaintiff do not of themselves create a cause of action in tort."

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s failure to take reasonable steps to prevent such an occurrence was a breach of the standard of care owed to customers like Plaintiff.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This is a dissenting opinion focused on lack of proximate causation, not on whether defendants breached a duty to take reasonable protective measures toward the plaintiff. Although the dissent assumes arguendo that certain security measures were negligent, it concludes that plaintiff failed to prove those acts or omissions proximately caused the injury, and would have granted directed verdicts for defendants. It therefore does not affirm or establish that defendants’ failure to take reasonable steps was a breach of the standard of care to persons like the plaintiff, and in any event is not the majority holding.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “I agree that the jury could have found that the system for locking the room door was inadequate due to the defendants’ negligence, but I do not agree that the jury could have found that entry into the room was gained by disengaging a lock. … In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor.”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312 (200.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries, including her mild concussion, shoulder strain, medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that the Commonwealth’s alleged negligence in paroling MacNeil was not the proximate (legal) cause of Officer Kent’s injuries, because intervening actions by INS were a superseding cause. The court concludes, as a matter of law, that plaintiffs cannot establish proximate causation and orders dismissal of the negligence claims. This is the opposite of the proposition that defendant’s negligence was a direct and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries and related damages.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312 (200.relevant_excerpt: “[T]here is no set of facts that the plaintiffs could prove to support a conclusion that the Commonwealth’s decision to parole MacNeil to the INS deportation warrant in 1987 was the proximate cause of Kent’s injuries in 1995. The Commonwealth’s motion to dismiss the claims for negligence should have been allowed.”

Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.raw_text: Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317 (2002)
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant is responsible not only for its own acts and omissions, but also vicariously for the negligent acts and omissions of its employees, agents, and servants acting within the scope of their employment under the doctrine of respondeat superior.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly applies traditional Massachusetts respondeat superior principles to a physician practice group, holding that an employer is vicariously liable for the torts of its employee-physicians committed within the scope of employment. The court rejects any special control requirement for medical decisions and states that, once an employment relationship is established, the only remaining question is whether the negligent act occurred within the scope of that employment. This squarely supports the proposition that a defendant-employer is responsible for the negligent acts and omissions of its employees, agents, and servants acting within the scope of their employment.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.relevant_excerpt: “Broadly speaking, respondeat superior is the proposition that an employer, or master, should be held vicariously liable for the torts of its employee, or servant, committed within the scope of employment… To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA. … ‘An employer is liable for torts committed by employees while acting in the scope of their employment.’”

Mirageas v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 391.raw_text: Mirageas v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 391 Mass. 815 (1984)
Mirageas v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 391.proposition: As a direct and foreseeable result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff has suffered and will continue to suffer bodily injury, pain and suffering, mental anguish, loss of enjoyment of life, lost wages, and medical expenses, and is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all such damages.
Mirageas v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 391.case_name: Mirageas v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Mirageas v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 391.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns comparative negligence, statutory construction, interest on judgments, and excessiveness of a jury award. It does not set out or discuss the specific categories of tort damages listed in the proposition (pain and suffering, mental anguish, loss of enjoyment of life, lost wages, medical expenses) or state any rule that a plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for those elements as a direct and foreseeable result of negligence. The case therefore does not provide authority for the detailed damages proposition quoted.
Mirageas v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 391.relevant_excerpt: On September 21, 1982, the jury returned a special verdict. The jury found that the MBTA had been 80% at fault in causing the accident, and Mirageas 20% at fault. The jury further found that Mirageas would have been entitled to damages of $1,900,000 if he had not been negligent. Accordingly, judgment was entered for Mirageas on September 22, 1982, in the amount of $1,520,000. ... On the record presented in this case, we think that the damages awarded to Mirageas were not greatly disproportionate to his injury, nor do we think that they represented a miscarriage of justice.

Haddad v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 455 Mas.raw_text: Haddad v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 455 Mass. 91 (2009)
Haddad v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 455 Mas.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover from Defendant all damages reasonably arising from Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, and any other allowable damages under Massachusetts law.
Haddad v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 455 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion is an employment discrimination case under Massachusetts General Laws c. 151B, not a negligence action. It discusses compensatory damages (including back pay, front pay, emotional distress) and punitive damages in the discrimination context, but nowhere addresses a defendant’s liability for all damages reasonably arising from negligence or lists the specific categories of tort damages described in the proposition. Therefore it does not provide authority for the negligence-damages rule stated.
Haddad v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 455 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "The jury awarded $17,700 in special damages, $125,000 in emotional distress damages, back pay of $95,000, and front pay of $733,307. See Stonehill College v. Massachusetts Comm’n Against Discrimination, 441 Mass. 549, 567-568, cert. denied sub nom. Wilfert Bros. Realty Co. v. Massachusetts Comm’n Against Discrimination, 543 U.S. 979 (2004) (to effectuate remedial purpose of statute, compensatory damages include those which are ‘natural and probable consequences’ of discriminatory act)."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, Plaintiff is also entitled to prejudgment interest on any damages awarded for personal injuries from the date of commencement of this action.

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: To the extent Defendant may assert that the actions of a third party (the other customer) were the sole cause of Plaintiff’s injuries, such defense is invalid because the risk that another customer might bump the shelves with a cart is precisely the type of normal, foreseeable customer conduct that Defendant had a duty to anticipate and protect against.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: This excerpt (a concurrence) states that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. That is the opposite of the claimed proposition, which relies on customer cart-bumping being a normal, foreseeable risk that the defendant had a duty to anticipate. The case, at least as reflected here, does not endorse the idea that another customer’s actions are a foreseeable risk the defendant must protect against; it finds the harm not reasonably foreseeable.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."
